Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2018 06:51PM Cowgirl13 wrote: Hi nc, I had no ida what DIPH radiation was until I googled it---"Deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) – Utilized for left-sided breast cancer radiotherapy to protect against long-term radiation damage to the heart." I had this protocol and it was really easy and the nurses told me I did a good job with it. You just hold your breath for a very short while (it's easy) while they radiate. I believe its also called gated. My radiation was done 9 years ago and I have no problems with my heart.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2009 01:01AM Cowgirl13 wrote: I was miserable for about 10 days after I had my port put in.  Had it just put in a week before chemo started--and I thought I was going to just be free and have a good time in the week before chemo started--wrong!!! That said, I am so glad I got a port.  I go in for infustions every week as I am on Herceptin and and every third week i have TCH.  My oncologists office is so great--they have the infusion room right there and it is the nicest room in all the offices--glass on 2 sides with a wonderful view.  Just excellent oncology nurses.  One of the best things is that before they access my port, they spray this cold feelingh stuff over the port area and it numbs the skin and I don't feel anything.  They even use this stuff even if you have used the numbing creme prior.  So since you are so sensitive right now, ask them if they will do this for you.  Insist on it as it really helps. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2013 05:34PM Cowgirl13 wrote: Tobo, you are so lucky Beesie responded right away.  I always read her comments as she is so knowledgeable and communicates so clearly.  I recently had some calcifications and I was ok watching for 6 months and at the end nothing had changed.  I will say, however, I was pretty comfortable waiting because I knew not much could happen in 6 months.  They have remained stable. What I would like to touch on is the positive side of getting a biopsy out of the way now--the only reason being the anxiety you feel.  Biopsy is a simple procedure and within a week you will know for sure what is going on.  And since most biopsy's turn out to be benign 80% of the time--you could just get on with your life and hopefully not have to worry about it. As a person who can be very anxious myself, I just wanted to give the 'anxiety' perspective. Good luck. Lizzie

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2010 10:20PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 06:19AM by Cowgirl13 TonLee, i am also triple positive.  Did TCH.  It was never a question of whether or not I would have neulesta.  I did.  My oncologist is very well respected and i felt comfortable with his recommendations.  Personally, I would do the Neulesta. If you counts go too low, they will not give you chemo until your counts are normal.   There was one time i showed up for chemo and they couldn't do it based on my blood and platelet counts even though i was taking neulesta..  Remember, while going thru chemo you will have an impaired immune system, if your counts go lower, you will be susceptable to illness.  Also, do get the steriods--they prevent allergic reaction. Good luck on our first chemo--i was terrified I would blow up in the chair!  I loved my chemo team and always felt so well cared for.  It sounds strange but I miss them.
